dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 4.2 magnitude earthquake just hit the Tengiz oil field in Kazakhstan, and it's a fascinating case of how we detect seismic events.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An earthquake occurred at the Tengiz oil field in western Kazakhstan on May 11, citing Ak Zhaiyk. The earthquake had a magnitude of 4.2, with the hypocenter located at a depth of 10 kilometers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the USGS picked it up, and it was at a depth of ten kilometers.

dialogue_turns.text: Right, and workers on site actually felt it, even though the Ministry of Emergency Situations said it wasn't felt by the general population.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the information, the tremor was reported by workers at the site and the United States Geological Survey (USGS).
